windows.symptom: Windows Live Mail won't connect to Telco server...saying Authorization needed        can access Microsoft account just not Windows Live Mail..Telco company have assured my no them which makes sense as can access emails on other programs just not Windows Live Mail
solutions: HI Katherine. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Moderator here to help you.Windows Live Mail has been discontinued for three years, and is actively being shut down, with dire warnings for over a year that features would be shut off soon:https://www.computerworld.com/article/3067121/e... I would migrate now to WIndows 10 Mail which is comparable except that it doesn't store any mail but is only a sync service for you web and Office Mail boxes. There's a full guide to set it up and use it here:https://www.windowscentral.com/how-get-started-... I have no problems using WIndows 10 mail for several years now to sync all of my web mail boxes, like the ability to merge inboxes (or not) and the huge ad-free reading pane.Note that you may need to uninstall all Windows Live Essentials to get WLM out completely so it doesn't keep claim as default Mail app and you can choose a new one in Settings > Apps > Default Apps.If you have Mail you need to export to another Mail program, I would do it now while you still can as shown here:https://archive.codeplex.com/?p=windowslivemail...https://www.experts-exchange.com/questions/2907...https://webapps.stackexchange.com/questions/496...I hope this helps. Feel free to ask back any questions and let us know how it goes. I will keep working with you until it's resolved.________________________________________________________ Standard Disclaimer: There are links to non-Microsoft websites. The pages appear to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the sites that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the sites before you decide to download and install it.

windows.symptom: Power off with out warning.        I am using Sony Vaio laptop operating on Window 10. Whenever the lap top operating on low battery mode, it shuts off with out any warning message saying " battery low, please switch on power supply". Hence it is a problem, when you are working on important file, laptop goes off with out any warning. Is there anyway you can  avoid it by changing any settings?
solutions: Hi UdayShetty, I am an independent advisor and a Microsoft user like you, and I would be happy to help you out with this.Can you confirm for us, when this happens, are you operating on battery only, and you do not have the power adapter plugged in?Sony stopped selling their Vaio line of computers in 2014, so the laptop you are using is likely 6 years old at the newest. During this amount of time, laptop batteries deplete and do not hold charge well anymore. This is why there is not much time between the warning and the actual shut down of the computer. If you can find a new compatible battery, this would be one way to help. Another option is to keep the wall power adapter plugged in constantly if possible.I hope this has helped you. If this is not what you are looking for, please reply and let us know and we would be happy to look into providing some different suggestions!Regards, -Ashton

windows.symptom: How do I change the output port to the loudspeaker output port?        I have a new computer (a few days old).  A Windows Audio Troubleshooter popped up and I used it. Basically, I tried it out and the volume was a little low and I decided to change the output port to another one (a headphone output.)  Then the the audio didn't work at all!!!  Now I can't change it back to the original port.  How do I change it back or if necessary reset the audio settings or if necessary, how would I reload Windows?
solutions: Hi Wolf. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Moderator here to help you.To reset the sound ports so they again prompt for what you plugged in, see here: https://windowsreport.com/you-just-plugged-unpl... (avoid ad links)https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Audio/En...https://forums.tomshardware.com/threads/how-do-...https://www.dell.com/community/Windows-10/How-g...https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/for...I'll give you all possible solutions for Sound problems in order of priority, so please try any you've already tried again in order. If you have any problems performing any steps I'll be standing by here to help you.1) Update the sound driver from the PC or device maker's Support Downloads webpage for your exact model, if it is newer than the one presently installed in Device Manager reached by right clicking the Start button. While there compare to make sure you also have the latest BIOS, Chipset, Display, Network and all other drivers. 2) Restore the Windows Audio Service which may have become disabled: https://www.tenforums.com/tutorials/57567-resto... 3) Next try these checklists: https://support.microsoft.com/en-in/help/402699... https://www.howtogeek.com/443702/how-to-fix-sou...4) Right click Volume icon in System Tray, choose Sound Settings, from the Output and Input devices dropdown menus, choose then one(s) affected to see if that helps. If not use the Troubleshoot button nearby.5) Run the Playing Sound troubleshooter at Start button > Settings>Update & Security>Troubleshoot.6) Try rolling back the sound drivers in Device Manager reached by right clicking the Start button. Choose Sound controller and other audio devices, then Driver tab, then Roll back if available.7) If no newer sound drivers then uninstall the one presently installed in Device Manager, reached by right clicking the Start Button. Restart PC to reinstall.8) Try other and older drivers for your model Sound controller, too. For example, try the next oldest driver in the model's online Support Downloads list. To try all previous drivers installed on your system, in Device Manager choose Sound controller's Driver tab, then Update Driver, then Browse, then Let Me Pick. Finally, try installing the latest Sound driver in Compatibility Mode as shown here:https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/win...9) If this was caused by Windows Updates then you can check which were installed at Settings>Update & Security>Windows Update under Installed Updates, then uninstall them from the link there, and hide with the Hide Updates tool downloaded from here:http://download.microsoft.com/download/f/2/2/f2... 10) If this was caused by a Version update (which you can confirm at Settings > System > About) then you can roll back the version in Settings>Update & Security>Recovery and then hide it until it matures using the Hide Updates Tool downloaded from here:http://download.microsoft.com/download/f/2/2/f2... 11) You can also use System Restore to get before the problem began, then check for Updates with the Hide Update tool and hide them:http://home.bt.com/tech-gadgets/computing/how-t... 12) Go over this checklist to make sure the install is set up correctly, optimized for best performance, and any needed repairs get done:http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wiki... Start with Step 4 to turn off Startup freeloaders which can conflict and cause issues, then Step 7 to check for infection the most thorough way, then step 10 to check for damaged System Files. Then continue with the other steps to go over your install most thoroughly. 13) If nothing else helps then run a Repair Install by installing the Media Creation Tool and choosing from it to Upgrade Now. This solves many problems and will also bring it up to the latest version which you need anyway and by the most stable method.http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-10/m... I hope this helps. Feel free to ask back any questions and let us know how it goes. I will keep working with you until it's resolved.________________________________________________________ Standard Disclaimer: There are links to non-Microsoft websites. The pages appear to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the sites that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the sites before you decide to download and install it.
On the taskbar click on the speaker, if after the title there is an ^ click on it and pick a different title.

windows.symptom: NIC adapter setting got changed automatically        On Windows 10 system NIC adapter setting for IPv4 was set as Static IP and after restarting the system it got automatically changed to Obtain automatically  IP.Please advise us How could this happen
solutions: Hello Vengatakrishnan, My name is Don and I am a Windows 10 Independent Adviser. Was there any device like Router or Modem connected to your computer when you restarted it?Was your NIC also set intentionally as Static IP to be able to connect to your internet provider or are they using Dynamic IP to provide you with internet access?

Hello Don,It was connected from LAN switch and after restarting the system we were experiencing this issue.The NIC was set as static to access the internet. We were using the static IP but suddenly it start taking the Invalid IP 169.254....

Hello Vengatakrishnan, Do you still have a copy of the Static IP settings for your internet connection? If you do, try to unplug the LAN switch first from your computer, reconfigure the Static IP settings on your IPv4 advanced settings and then restart the computer.Once the computer has restarted, recheck to see if the Static IP settings are still there then reconnect your computer to the LAN switch and see if you could access the internet.Let me know how it goes.

Hello Don, Good Day Actually we have resolved the issue now. we have changed the NIC adapter to static now and it working fine we can access the internet.But why it got auto changed to obtain auto Any reason. It would be appreciated

Hello Vengatakrishnan, From my own personal point of view as a Technical Support Analyst of more than a decade now, there are several factors that could be the cause of the issue. One could be an outdated network adapter driver or a faulty NIC, another could be a bad registry being stored and getting corrupt, and lastly firewall settings. Whatever the cause is, it is always good to perform system and driver updates from time to time and do system defragmentation. It is also good to perform isolation checks like replacing network cables or replicating the issue on another computer so as to determine where the issue is coming from.
Hello Don, Yours message well noted.Thanks for quick assist

Hello Vengatakrishnan, You're very much welcome. If you have any other issues please feel free to message us again and we'll be glad to assist you. I will now be marking this issue as resolved.Regards

solutions: nao estou conseguindo instalar o windows 10 no meu computador esta dando erro 0x8007001F e 0x20006 como fasso para instalar?
Anyone has an ideas?

SOLVEDFile System32\inetsrv\config\ApplicationHost.config was empty, I replaced it with file applicationhost.config.clean.install from this folder (I guess you can find it in Internet if there is no such file), then launch service WAS "Windows process activation service", then installed Windows 1903 update successfully.

SOLVEDFile System32\inetsrv\config\ApplicationHost.config was empty, I replaced it with file applicationhost.config.clean.install from this folder (I guess you can find it in Internet if there is no such file), then launch service WAS "Windows process activation service", then installed Windows 1903 update successfully.I'm not able to run the "Windows process activation service" I get the following message when I try to restart.Windows could not start the Windows Process Activation Service service on Local Computer.Error 2: The system cannot find the file specified.

This advice actually helped me to kick the update to finish successfully. In my case the mentioned file ApplicationHost.config contained some binary data, and I had not one but three applicationhost.config.clean.install files in the same folder with the same content. I have replaced the binary data with clean xml from the first .install and everything gone smoothly. As I haven't touched ISS at all, it seems it broke itself after some update. I can provide the binary data file is that will help anyone to debug this issue. But without this manual intervention the update seems to be impossible, which is sad.

But without this manual intervention the update seems to be impossible, which is sad.Hi Spurlos89,Can you share the file with me, as stated above...?

At last, a solution that works! I simply saved applicationHost.config as applicationHost.config.old then renamed applicationhost.config.clean.install as applicationHost.config then ran the update. I feel like I've won the lottery!

Thanks this was the solution to fixing my Windows 10 upgrade from 1803 to 1903 as well. After a week of trying trial and error solutions and looking in vain at logs in the Windows directory I finally found the actual error in $WINDOWS.~BT\Sources\Panther\setupact.log that led me to your post.BTW the date on my corrupted ApplicationHost.config file was 5/14/2018 and looking back at my notes that was the date that I did the 1803 update so I suspect that is what caused it.
Here is the file uploaded to Firefox Sendhttps://send.firefox.com/download/b77539e4d0f95837/#wrEZKZ_vpox8Cd0_4e5WSw

Here is the file uploaded to Firefox Sendhttps://send.firefox.com/download/b77539e4d0f95837/#wrEZKZ_vpox8Cd0_4e5WSwHi Spurlos89, thanks for sharing the above attachment, it didn't work on my system.Although, I was able to successfully update to 1903 build, after performing the below steps...Go to your RSA machine keys folder: C:\Users\All Users\Application Data\Microsoft\Crypto\RSA\MachineKeysFind a machine key (file) whose name starts with d6d986f09a1ee04e24c949879fdb506c_*. windows.symptom: Is there a way to FORCE update from Windows 1803 to 1909        For about 6 months I have been trying to update my desktop PC from Windows 10 1803 to 1903 and more recently 1909 and it fails with the following error message:upgrade error 0xC1900101 - 0x30018   The installation failed in the FIRST_BOOT phase with an error in SYSPREP_SPECIALIZE operationI have read everything I can find on the internet about this error and have run all fixes and troubleshooters that  I can find,  several of the scans have reported issues initially and those issues have been fixed.     Now none of the scans or troubleshooters reports an issue.   But the upgrade still fails with this error.The hardware on my PC is completely modern (Ryzen 3900x on Asus X370 motherboard)  and I have nothing plugged in but keyboard ,mouse, and monitor.  Rebuilding my PC from scratch is not an option  because I don't have installation means on several of the old apps on my computer that I don't want to lose.   It would be awesome if there was a way to force the upgrade to complete.     I think it would be easier to fix any broken device AFTER the upgrade, than trying over and over again to get this very slow upgrade process to complete.      I have a disk image to go back to if the forced-upgrade-system was not bootable.      Is there a way to force the Upgrade process to complete in spite of a driver error?
solutions: Hi Joe, Click the link below, then click 'Update Now' on that page to immediately get 1909 and bring your PC right up to datehttps://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-downlo...If you have any difficulty with that 'Update Now' link, with these major upgrades, the most successful method is to upgrade from the Windows 10 ISO - you download the ISO and then perform an Offline UpgradePlease Note, follow the steps, this is then just an update and your files and applications will remain untouched . . .Click this link: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-downlo...to download the Media Creation Tool (Click on Download Tool Now), with that you can download the latest Windows 10 ISO (Select Create Installation Media for Another PC), then choose ISO, not USBWhen the ISO file completes downloading Disconnect from the Internet Temporarily disable any 3rd party Anti-virus you may have installed Then, in Windows File Explorer, double click the ISO and then run Setup.exe to begin the upgrade . . .

Hey Dave,Thanks for your response.    Although, doing what you advised did not solve my problem.   I kept having the same issue again:upgrade error 0xC1900101 - 0x30018   The installation failed in the FIRST_BOOT phase with an error in SYSPREP_SPECIALIZE operationHowever, I have found the solution to the problem I have been having for the last 18 months and innumerable attempts to upgrade to Windows 1809, 1903, and 1909!!    UNBELIEVABLE!!!!By googling the specific error in the setupact.log and setuperr.log files I was able to find the following post:https://answers.microsoft.com/The quick solution saving you from parsing through that thread:Run powershell (running as Admin): Run the following two commands:cd  c:\Windows\ System32\inetsrv\config\ copy applicationhost.config.clean.install .\applicationHost.configSomehow the applicationHost.config file got corrupted.   By replacing the corrupted file with the applicationhost.config.clean.install file in the same directory, then VOILA - the upgrade to 1909 works. Some things I did along many tries at getting my system upgraded that may have helped, but at least didn't hurt and cleaned up my system at least:1) Remove all devices from the system except keyboard, mouse, and monitor2) Delete every driver of a non-essential device in the system3) Deleting all old appsincluding old drivers that I didn't needFrom Powershell (Run as admin):4)   chkdsk /f     (followed by reboot)5)     sfc /scannow6)     dism /online /cleanup-image /scanhealth7)    dism /online /cleanup-image /restorehealth8)    dism /online /cleanup-image /startcomponentcleanup9)  Download application   CCleaner and run all the different cleanup functions, in particular the Registry cleanup functions.    Keep running the commands until they come up clean10)   run the upgrade from the Windows MediaCreationTool,   download the image into an ISO file as Dave described above.WHEW,  I can't tell you how many times I tried to upgrade over the last 16 months without success.   I hope this helps someone else banging their head against this issue to get past it in less time than it took me.

Split from this thread.gotten computer from friend , never noticed it before it wasn't genuine  andI didn't have the code?I suggest that you ask your friend where they got Windows 7 from and how they bought it.They may have bought a Retail license or it may have come preinstalled (Dell, HP, etc.)Is it a Retail, OEM System Builders or OEM preinstalled (Dell, HP, etc.) license and is it still activated?@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@The Product Key consists of 25 digits, divided into 5 groups of 5 digits and the layout looks like this:xxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxxThe 24 used are:2346789BCDFGHJKMPQRTVWXYThe 12 unused are:015AEILNOSUZ@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@If installed and activated and a Retail or OEM system Builders license and you have lost the product key that came with the purchase use these free programs:http://www.belarc.com/free_download.htmlhttps://www.magicaljellybean.com/keyfinder/@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@If you bought it from Microsoft:Find your downloads and product keysMost software you buy directly from Microsoft Store as a digital download, like Office, Windows, and Xbox games, can be downloaded, installed, or reinstalled inorder history. Find the software and then selectProduct key/Install.@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@If OEM preinstalled (Dell, HP, etc.) license:The COA sticker, which has the Product Key on it, is either on the underside of the Laptop or in the Battery Compartment.With a Desktop it is either on the side, rear or top of the Computer Case.Product Key finder programs do NOT find a useable product key on OEM preinstalled operating systems (Dell, HP, etc.)Key Finder Programs used on preinstalled Operating Systems only find the Manufacturer's Product Key which was used on multiple machines during manufacture and what they find is not suitable to use for a reinstall or activation problems.

What a mess. There's no System partition on C so it can't convert to GPT because a UEFI install requires that 100mb EFI System partition.There should be a System Active flag on the partition that's actually booting C, so it may be the partition at the right end of the C drive which is marked Active but not System. If so then the converter is probably ignoring it because it lacks the necessary System flag. But it could also be the Active partition on the last disk which looks like a 32gb flash stick was intended to be created by Media Creation Tool from the front end of a 2tb hard drive, then the rest was formatted as a Data partition later. The data partition says it's Seagate removable, but Disk Mgmt thinks it's a fixed drive. I would choose your fastest SSD and wipe the drive of all partitions, correctly install to UEFI following the gold standard Clean Install in this link which compiles the best possible Install of Windows which will stay that way as long as you stick with the tools and methods given, has zero reported problems, and is better than any amount of money could buy:http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wiki...
